awd_titl_txt: Quadrupedal Robot Running:  Control Synthesis Harnessing Compliance
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this award is to offer a control synthesis framework for feedback laws that harness compliance to realize agile locomotion in a class of robotic quadrupeds. To achieve this goal, a modeling and control hierarchy that transforms nature-inspired reductive models of locomotion behavior into concrete control commands to the robots? actuators is proposed. If successful, this research effort will impact the study of many other engineered and biological systems, which, like legged robots, accomplish their purpose through forceful, cyclic interactions with their environment. Deliverables include models of locomotion behavior; analytical methods to rigorously characterize cyclic motion generation and stability of quadrupedal running gaits; constructive control techniques and systematic control law design tools that minimize laborious, trial-and-error experimentation; verification procedures to test the controllers in a variety of running gaits using widely accepted performance metrics; and engineering student education and engineering research experiences for K-12 teachers.

This work directly addresses a principal barrier to innovation that faces the legged robotics community today: systematic controller design tools that enable legged machines to perform real-world tasks reliably and efficiently. This way, this research effort promotes the advancement of a host of real-life applications, including industrial, agricultural and military applications, which require highly mobile and versatile robot platforms. In the long run, this work will lead to increased public acceptance and more pervasive use of robots. In addition, graduate and undergraduate engineering students will benefit through active participation in the research process. An integral part of this effort is to immerse K-12 teachers in engineering research experiences, with the purpose of translating those experiences into classroom activities to enhance their standards-based curriculum.

Objectives and Motivation:

The goal of this project is the realization of reliable and efficient running robots through a modeling and control design approach that combines stability and performance guarantees with fast and elegant motions. Out of the many reasons for exploring the use of legs for locomotion, one stands out: mobility. There is a need for vehicles that can travel over rough terrain, where wheeled or tracked vehicles cannot traverse. By providing systematic methods for control design, this research will enable legged machines to perform real-world tasks reliably and efficiently. This way, our effort promotes the advancement of a host of real-life applications -- including industrial, agricultural and emergency response applications -- that require highly mobile and versatile robot platforms. In the long run, this research will contribute to increased public acceptance and more pervasive use of robots.

Intellectual Merit:

This project introduced mathematical models, analysis techniques, and feedback control synthesis methods for a class of highly dynamic legged robots that employ active or passive compliance to realize running motions. We have also introduced a novel actuation scheme for running robots that combines energy efficiency with enhanced control authority over the system.

At the core of our modeling hierarchy is the idea of encoding desired locomotion behaviors via suitable reduced-order conceptual models. These mathematical models capture the principles underlying the mechanics of locomotion behaviors without explicit reliance on the fine structural and morphological characteristics of the physical system at hand. In other words, these models offer unifying, platform-independent descriptions of desired task-level locomotion behaviors. Through this project we have developed and rigorously characterized a family of conceptual models for quadrupedal running gaits. We have employed these models to design control laws suitable for stabilizing running tasks on quadrupedal robots by using feedback to coordinate the higher-dimensional robot plant into a lower-dimensional conceptual model that encodes the desired locomotion behavior, literally interpreting the proposed models as behavioral targets for the control system.

Beyond robot control, to demonstrate the predictive capabilities of our modeling hierarchy, we have used it to estimate the metabolic cost of transport of running quadrupedal animals. Despite the simple structure of the models, and the fact that certain parameters are difficult to extract from available animal data, it was demonstrated that the model-predicted energy cost of transport matches exceptionally well the metabolic cost of transport estimated using measurements of oxygen consumption from running animals, including the horse, the cheetah, the dog and the gazelle. These results can be useful to biomechanists and biologists in generating hypotheses and making predictions about energy consumption in running quadrupedal animals, and in quantifying the effect of inertia and stiffness properties of animal bodies on gait energetics.

In addition to mathematical modeling and control algorithms for running robots, part of our effort has been devoted to the mechanical design of such robots. Running robots typically operate in regimes where the natural dynamics of the mechanical system imposes strict limitations on the capability of the motors to guide the robot’s motion. Furthermore, the pressure for extended power autonomous operation calls for increased energy efficiency.
